sourceDesc.p: Drafted using output from listAtts.xml, and overview in TEI EDW79.

list.item: 22 Apr 05LB: revised taking in Syd's comments of 20/4

body.head: Principles for rationalisation of TEI attributes in P5, in particular for the disposition of Text-valued attributes

div.p: This note summarizes what I believe we have already decided to do, and indeed in some cases -- but not all -- have already done. It also includes some proposals which have not yet been explicitly discussed, but which I believe to be necessary to achieve a coherent overview. The main objective is to rationalise the current inconsistencies in the ways attribute values are used.

Before P5 there was an unstated principle that the element content of a TEI document should represent all and only the unmarked up text: the idea of SGML/XML markup was new, and people needed to be reassured that their data was still there intact "underneath" the tags. With the introduction of choice we have turned our back on this rather na√Øve view of the scope of mark up, rightly or wrongly, but irrevocably. It makes sense therefore to see how far we can go in the direction of reversing the assumption that anything not actually there on the source page should be stuffed away in an attribute value.

Before P5, the facilities available for constraining legal attribute values were limited to what the DTD language would support. Moreover, to use those facilities required a degree of sophisticated knowledge about how to modify the DTD. In P5, the new ODD mechanism makes it very much easier to do the job properly by writing a project-specific ODD containing explicitly documented valLists from which a project-specific schema can be generated. We can afford therefore to simplify and make more explicit the constraints in the released schemas.

div.head: Data types
div.p:
I propose that we define a set of TEI datatypes and constrain all attributes to use one of them. For the most part, the underlying XSD datatype is obvious, and we might prefer to use those instead, but I suggest that the discipline of using only a small number of predefined and predocumented datatypes may be good for us and certainly easier for the end-user. We should of course explicitly map each TEI datatype directly to an XSD datatype; I have not yet done this in the following tentative list of proposals:
tei.target a single URI reference
tei.targets a whitespace delimited list of the foregoing
tei.token any string of Unicode chars excluding whitespace xsd:token { pattern = "^[^ ]+$" }
tei.tokens a whitespace delimited list of the foregoing
tei.numeric any single quantitative indication (int, real, perc, etc.) xsd:decimal | xsd:token { pattern = "-?[0-9]+\.?[0-9]*%" }
tei.tempexp any indication of time/date
tei.uboolean any indication of truth/falsity/uncertainty
tei.lang a token which corresponds with a standard language code (xsd:language)

In many cases the datatype per se will not give sufficient validation: for example while all possible values for an attribute "sex" are likely to be tei.token, they are few in number and should be constrained. In such cases a valList should be used: it's debatable whether we might also want to define something like tei.enumerated to mean one of the tokens defined in an associated value list.

div.head: Value lists and the type attribute
div.p:
Specification of possible list item values in the current ODDs varies greatly. Sometimes suggested values are given in a valDesc as "for example". Where lists of values are supplied, they may be within a vallist of type="closed", "open", or "semi", but it's not always clear on what basis the distinction is to be made, and it certainly is not consistently applied. It relates to conformance which is a murky area anyway. Suggested correct practice should be
sample values should not be given in the valDesc
sample values and their meanings should always be given for attributes with datatypes tei.token or tei.tokens
sample values should always be given in a valList with an appropriate value for its type attribute. Maybe "semi" should be renamed something else.
Open question: is a schema TEI-conformant if it disallows some of the existing values in a valList? is an application TEI-conformant if (when using a modified schema in which one of the existing values has been disallowed) it rejects such a value? My answers are respectively Yes and No, but I'm not sure.

The type attribute poses this problem in acute form. At present, we have a mixture of
type is explicitly defined on an element but with CDATA content
type is explicitly defined on an element with a suggested value list
type is implied by membership of the element in tei.typed
This variety simply reflects the fact that for some elements we have a fairly clear idea of what the likely values are, and for others we haven't the faintest idea. I think that the way to support this is as follows:
anything that carries a type attribute is ipso facto a member of tei.typed
this gets you a type attribute defined as tei.token (and also a subtype, if you care to use it)
elements where we want the Guidelines to make helpful suggestions for type values do so by including a redefinition of type with more specific valLists (typed as open or semi) for those elements in their ODD

Note that we have made it impossible for type to be tei.tokens, and we have also made it impossible for its values to include whitespace. I don't regard either of these as mistakes, though they may discombobulate some current TEI users.

div.head: Real text and where to put it
div.p:
Attributes which at P4 may genuinely contain "real text" must become child elements. There are two tests for something being "real text":
it uses some specific natural language and would require translation (ergo its xml:lang might be different)
it might potentially contain such markup elements as g or graphic

EDW79 lists the attribute/element combinations which satisfy this definition and proposes in several cases how to address the requirement that attributes become elements. In general, the following procedure is proposed:
Assuming an element E with textual attributes A1 ... An.
If E is declared as an empty element, then we simply define its content model to permit new elements named A1 to An (some rationalisation of names may be possible and it may even be feasible to define a class for all such new elements).
If E is not empty, then we must declare a new element E', whose content model will be new elements named A1 to An, as in the empty element case, followed by the element E.

EDW79 also proposes some exceptions to these general rules:
There are several attributes for which the choice element seems a more natural solution
The reg attribute used to provide regularised forms of several elements in the names class could be replaced by a pointer attribute, or a child element, possibly within a choice
the index element needs special treatment.
several elements in the dictionary module needs revision for consistency with practice elsewhere

div.head: Some open issues
div.p: We have two attributes used to indicate some degree of certainty: cert (values for which are undefined but probably something like high/medium/low) and certainty (which seems to offer more precision). Do we need them both? does anyone use them?

The suggested tei.numeric is a deliberately vague general class, intended to encompass a number of more precise datatypes (analogous therefore to tei.tempexp). For example, we might want to restrict some attribute values to a quantity which might be represented either as a real number in the range 0 to 1 or as a percentage; in other cases, it might make no sense to have any non-integral value, or to permit a negative value. We have nothing analogous to the valList to express these constraints on numeric values.

We use key for sort keys, and also for database-lookup codes which appear variously on elements in the tei.names, tei.personPart, and tei.temporalExpr classes; and also for analogous purposes on elements in the ODD system itself. There is clearly some scope for rationalization here. Should we make it a URI-valued attribute and use it also for regularization purposes?
We use resp more or less consistently to indicate a responsibility: this should probably be a tei.token; should it be treated in the same way as key?
loc on app is presumably not a canonical ref as we understand the phrase elsewhere. The whole question of canonical refs needs further thought and I am still not convinced we need them.
Several of the attributes defined in tei.dictionaries need revision, e.g. if norm just another sort of regularization shouldn't it be done with reg?

div.head: Summary
div.p: The following table lists all text-valued attributes currently defined for P5 in alphabetical order, indicating for each the intended course of action. The usage "xxx list e.g. yyy zzz" indicates that the ODD contains a valList of type xxx and gives some sample values. The usage "stet" means no change is proposed (i.e., for valListed items, it will be tei.token). The usage "child" indicates that the parent element gets tei.remarks as its child. Question marks indicate indecision.

row.cell: any prose description of the agency of damage.
any prose description of the agency of damage.
any prose description of the agent.
any prose description of the agent.
generic identifier, attribute value, location (e.g. indicated by a reference to an anchor element or to an ptr element), or other appropriate alternative value.
a string of characters representing the spelling of the morpheme's base form.
any convenient string for use as a name.
Recommended values include: Gregorian, Julian, Roman, Mosaic, Revolutionary, Islamic.
Recommended values include: Gregorian, Julian, Roman, Mosaic, Revolutionary, Islamic.
Recommended values include: Gregorian, Julian, Roman, Mosaic, Revolutionary, Islamic.
any word or phrase describing the cause: e.g. homeoteleuton, homeoarchy, paleographic confusion, haplography, dittography, false emendation.
Any appropriate value, e.g. ca., approx, after, before.
The name or initials of the person or institution responsible for creating this TEI header.
the result of applying the algorithm for the resolution of canonical references (described in section ) should be a valid URI reference that resolves to a term element
the result of applying the algorithm for the resolution of canonical references (described in section ) should be a valid URI reference to the intended target
the result of applying the algorithm for the resolution of canonical references (described in section ) should be a valid URI reference to the intended target
the result of applying the algorithm for the resolution of canonical references (described in section ) should be a valid URI reference that resolves to a gloss element
an alphanumeric categorization of the degree of damage, as 40%.
If a single space is used it is interpreted as whitespace.
tei.char (? or can it be a token?)
a prose description of how and why the markup is uncertain.
a prose description of the material omitted.
any string of characters, typically a phrase or sentence in a natural language.
Any word or phrase, such as stet or strike-down.
Any string of characters; usually a siglum conventionally used for the edition.
Any string of characters; usually a siglum conventionally used for the edition.
Any string of characters; usually a siglum conventionally used for the edition.
Any string of characters; usually a siglum conventionally used for the edition.
Any string of characters; usually a siglum conventionally used for the edition.
Any appropriate value, e.g. ca., approx, after, before.
any measurement phrase, e.g. 25 letters, 2 × 3 inches.
any measured quantity, e.g. 10 letters or 4 lines.
For a cl, may take values such as coordinate, subject, adverbial etc. For a phr, such values as subject, predicate etc. may be more appropriate.
the name of an element from the current dtd
a characterization of the conditions which are assumed in the assignment of a degree of confidence. This may be in prose.
an application-specific name, consisting of Unicode characters only.
any sequence of characters which, when sorted with the other values, will produced the desired order; specifics of key construction are application-dependent.
a string of characters representing the spelling of the word's dictionary entry form.
Any string containing a canonical reference for the passage to which the variation applies.
any string of characters; often, but not necessarily, numeric.
Should be the skeleton of a relative or absolute URI, with references to groups in the re.
any short indication of the reason for the omission.
any phrase describing the difficulty, e.g. overbinding, faded ink, lost folio, omitted in original.
any phrase describing the difficulty, e.g. faded, ambient noise, passing truck, ill formed, eccentric ductus.

must be one of the identifiers declared in the document header, associated with a person asserted as responsible for some aspect of the text's creation, transcription, editing, or encoding (see chapter ).
any string of characters, typically the initials of an individual, the acronym of an agency, the name of a computer program, etc.
Any string of characters, such as the initials of the encoder.

must be one of the identifiers declared in the document header, associated with a person asserted as responsible for some aspect of the text's creation, transcription, editing, or encoding (see chapter ).
The generic identifier of an element in the current DTD.
Any name, such as tremulous hand, Hand B, Hoccleve, used to identify a scribe
may contain a number and an indication of accuracy, e.g. approx 200
Should really be a bibliographic reference of some kind

any string of characters identifying the source of the supplied text. This might be the sigil for a manuscript, or a particular edition, or the transcriber or editor's own initials, indicating it as their conjecture.
any description of flaws in the marking of a deletion, e.g. excess left, excess right, short left, short right.
Any descriptive name such as secretary, copperplate, Chancery, Italian, etc.
Any descriptive name such as secretary, copperplate, Chancery, Italian, etc.

Any convenient descriptive word or phrase, describing the extent of the variation (e.g. word, phrase, punctuation, etc.) its text-critical significance (e.g. significant, accidental, unclear), or the nature of the variation or the principles required to understand it (e.g. lectio difficilior, usus auctoris, etc.)
any string of characters, e.g. preposition.
any phrase describing the damage, e.g. faded, overbound, water, charred with loss of paper.
add to tei.typed; clarify that this is not desc
any string identifying the class of deletion.
A name or abbreviation indicating what type of identifying number is given (e.g. ISBN, LCCN).
any string of characters, such as usage, sense restriction, etc.
Values such as person, place, institution, product, acronym.
The type should indicate the intended function of the pointer, or the rhetorical relationship between its source and target.
any string of characters. The range of permissible values is application dependent.
any string of characters. The range of permissible values is application dependent.
Any string, e.g. full, half, Series, etc.
a semi-closed list of recognized time units such as millisecond, second, minute
any available character or character sequence.
a list of numbers, in the range from 0 to 1 if wScale is real, and in the range from 0 to 100 if wScale is perc.
contains a word or phrase such as GMT or Eastern Standard Time which might be helpful in evaluating the temporal expression.
make listVals (and make it a bit less vague)
contains a word or phrase such as GMT or Eastern Standard Time defining a time zone.
make listVals (and make it a bit less vague)
